questions.text: Which culture method is useful in motility testing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Stab Culture

 

Explanation:

Stab Culture is made by stabbing the semisolid agar butt with a straight wire.

It is used for motility testing using

  • Mannitol motility medium and
  • Triple sugar iron agar test.

CULTURE TECHNOLOGIES

Culture Type

Uses

 Picture

Streak Culture (Option A)
  • Primary inoculum smeared onto solid media.
  • Secondary and tertiary inoculum formed by streaking parallel lines.
  • Intermittent heating to obtain isolated colonies.

Stroke Culture
  • Zigzag streaking on agar slopes or slants.
  • Used for biochemical tests like urease test.

Lawn Culture (Option C)
  • Uniform bacterial growth is obtained by swabbing or flooding.
  • Used for antimicrobial susceptibility testing (AST) by disk diffusion method.

Stab Culture (Option D)
  • Agar butt stabbed with straight wire.
  • Used for motility testing and triple sugar iron agar test.

Liquid Culture (Option B)
  • Used for blood or body fluids.
  • Bacterial growth is detected by turbidity or surface pellicles.
  • Advantages: Suitable for specimens with antibiotics, large yields.
  • Disadvantages: It doesn't provide pure culture from mixed inoculum, and no visible colonies.

questions.text: Which of the following describes the correct process used in the pour plate technique?

choices.text: Adding the sample onto the solidified agar surface and allowing colonies to grow
Use a glass spreader to evenly distribute the sample on the surface of molten agar
Colonies grow primarily on the surface

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Adding the sample onto the solidified agar surface and allowing colonies to grow.

Explanation:

  • In the pour plate method, the sample is added onto the solidified agar surface allowing colonies to grow.
  • This allows for the colonies to grow both within the agar medium and on its surface, facilitating the enumeration of various types of bacteria including aerobes, anaerobes, and facultative anaerobes.
  • Advantages:
    • Provides quantitative data on viable bacterial count per ml of the original sample.
    • Allows visualization and counting of individual colonies.

Feature

Pour Plate Technique

Spread Plate Technique

Process

The sample is added onto the solidified agar surface.

The sample is mixed with molten agar and poured.

Accuracy

Generally considered more accurate.

Slightly less accurate compared to the pour plate.

Sample Spreading

The sample is not spread; colonies grow within agar.

The sample is spread using a glass spreader. (Option C)

Types of Bacteria

Aerobes, anaerobes, facultative anaerobes.

Aerobes only.

Medium State

Solidified agar plates are necessary.

Molten agar medium is used (Option A).

Visibility of Colonies

Colonies can grow both within and on the surface of agar.

Colonies grow primarily on the surface. (Option D)
Image

questions.text: Which of the following statements about agar is TRUE?

choices.text: Agar has a high nutritional value for bacteria.
Agar melts at 42°C and solidifies at 98°C
Agar is derived from seaweed and is used to solidify culture media.
Solid media typically use a concentration of approximately 5% agar.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Agar is derived from seaweed and is used to solidify culture media.

 

Explanation:

 

Properties of Agar:

  • Agar is extracted from seaweed and is commonly used to solidify culture media for bacterial growth.
  • Agar has negligible nutritional value for bacteria; it is mainly used as a solidifying agent. (Option A ruled out)
  • Agar melts at 98°C and solidifies at around 42°C. (Option B ruled out)
  • Solid media typically use a concentration of approximately 2% agar. (Option D ruled out)

Simple media, also known as basal media, is a type of culture media used in laboratories to grow bacteria.

Simple Media

Nutrient Broth

 

  • Peptone
  • NaCl
  • Water
  • Meat Extract

 

Nutrient Agar

 

  • Peptone
  • NaCl
  • Water
  • Meat Extract
  • 2% Agar

questions.text: All of the following are examples of enriched media except
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) MacConkey agar

 

Explanation:

  • MacConkey agar is a selective and differential medium, not an enriched medium. It is used to isolate Gram-negative bacteria and differentiate them based on lactose fermentation.
  • Enriched media contain growth enhancers added to nonselective agar to support the growth of fastidious organisms.

Enriched Media

Name

Characteristics

 Image

Blood agar (Option A ruled out)

Base medium enriched with 5-10% defibrinated sheep blood, used to grow moderately fastidious bacteria and observe hemolytic reactions.

 

Chocolate agar (Option C ruled out)

This is an enriched medium made by heating blood agar, which lyses red blood cells and releases nutrients such as haemoglobin and NAD. It supports the growth of fastidious bacteria such as Haemophilus and Neisseria species.

Brain-heart infusion (BHI) broth (Option D ruled out)

This is an enriched medium containing nutrients from brains and beef hearts, along with peptones, glucose, sodium chloride, and buffers. It supports the growth of non-fastidious and moderately fastidious microorganisms.

Loeffler serum slope

An enriched medium with high serum content, prepared with eggs. Primarily used for the recovery and identification of Corynebacterium diphtheriae from nose and throat specimens.

Lowenstein-Jensen medium:

Used specifically for cultivating Mycobacterium species, this enriched, selective medium contains glycerol, mineral salts, aspargine, malachite green, and hen’s eggs.

questions.text: Which of the following enrichment broths is used to enhance the growth of group B streptococci?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Lim broth

Explanation:

Enrichment Broth:

  • Liquid media with inhibitory agents selectively promote the growth of specific organisms and inhibit others.
  • Used for isolating pathogens from clinical specimens containing normal flora (e.g., stool, sputum).

Examples:

1. Tetrathionate broth – Used for Salmonella Typhi isolation.

2. Gram-negative broth – Used for Shigella isolation.

3. Selenite F broth – Used for Shigella isolation.

4. Alkaline peptone water (APW) – Used for Vibrio cholerae isolation.

Lim Broth is an enrichment broth specifically used to enhance the growth of group B streptococci. It provides the necessary nutrients and conditions for the selective multiplication of these organisms.

Selenite F medium (Option A): This enrichment medium is used primarily for stool samples to suppress gut bacteria growth while allowing diarrheagenic bacteria (Salmonella, Shigella) to grow. It is not specific to group B streptococci.

Tetrathionate broth (Option B): This enrichment medium inhibits coliforms while allowing the growth of typhoid-paratyphoid bacilli.

Alkaline peptone water (Option D): This enrichment medium is used to recover Vibrio and Aeromonas species from stool samples.

questions.text: Which of the following selective media is used to isolate and differentiate Vibrio species based on their ability to ferment sucrose?

choices.text: Thiosulfate Citrate Bile Salts Sucrose (TCBS) Agar

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Thiosulfate Citrate Bile Salts Sucrose (TCBS) Agar

 

Explanation:

  • TCBS is a selective medium that inhibits gram-positive bacteria and many gram-negative rods with bile salts and other components.
  • It differentiates Vibrio species based on their ability to ferment sucrose, with sucrose fermenters producing yellow colonies and non-fermenters producing blue-green colonies.

 

Selective Media:

They are solid media containing inhibitory substances that inhibit the normal flora present in the specimen and allow the pathogens to grow.

Selective Media

Media

Property

   Image    

Mannitol Salt Agar (MSA)

(Option A ruled out)
  • The high salt concentration (7.5%) inhibits most bacteria, except Staphylococcus.
  • Staphylococcus aureus ferments mannitol, producing yellow colonies with a yellow zone, while other Staphylococci and Micrococcus sp. do not ferment mannitol and produce reddish colonies.

MacConkey Agar (MAC)

(Option B ruled out)
  • MacConkey Agar (MAC) consists of peptone, lactose, agar, neutral red, and taurocholate. It selectively and differentially isolates gram-negative enteric bacilli via lactose fermentation:
  • Lactose fermenters produce pink/red colonies, and
  • Non-fermenters produce colourless/transparent colonies.

Potassium Tellurite Media

(Option D ruled out)
  • Potassium tellurite media, like potassium tellurite blood agar and Tinsdale agar, selectively isolate Corynebacterium diphtheriae by inhibiting most other bacteria. C. diphtheriae reduces tellurite, forming grey to black colonies.

CLED Medium
  • A type of differential medium, akin to MacConkey agar, distinguishes between lactose fermenters (LF) and non-lactose fermenters (NLF).
  • It serves as a substitute for using both blood agar and MacConkey agar when processing urine samples.

 

Medium

Indicator

Colour

Mannitol Salt agar

S. aureus

Phenol red

MF (yellow)

TCBS

V. cholera

Bromothymol blue

Sucrose fermentation (yellow)

CLED

Bromothymol blue

Lactose fermentation (yellow)

Mac Conkey

Neutral red

Lactose fermentation (pink)

questions.text: Which medium is selectively used for isolating Pseudomonas aeruginosa from specimens with mixed microbiota?
questions.solution:
Correct answer D) Cetrimide Agar

 

Explanation:

  • Cetrimide agar is specifically formulated to select Pseudomonas aeruginosa by inhibiting most gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria except for P. aeruginosa and P. fluorescens.
  • It contains cetrimide, magnesium chloride, and potassium sulfate to enhance the growth and pigment production (pyocyanin) characteristic of Pseudomonas aeruginosa.

PPLO Agar (Option A): This medium isolates Mycoplasma species. Antimicrobials can be added to inhibit the growth of other bacteria.

 

DCA (Desoxycholate Citrate Agar) (Option B): They are employed to isolate gastrointestinal pathogens like Salmonella and Shigella from faecal specimens.

Thayer-Martin Medium (Option C): This selective medium is used to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae from clinical specimens. The medium contains the following antimicrobials, which suppress the growth of other organisms: vancomycin, colistin, and nystatin. Thayer-Martin plates are incubated in an atmosphere containing 3-10% CO2.

 

Other differential media & their characteristics

1. Polymyxin-Lysozyme-EDTA-Thallous Acetate (PLET) Medium:


 
  • Purpose: Isolates Bacillus anthracis from mixtures with other spore-bearing bacilli.
  • Key Components: Polymyxin, lysozyme, EDTA, thallous acetate, heart infusion agar.

2. Mannitol, Egg Yolk, Polymyxin B, Phenol Red, and Agar (MYPA):


 
  • Purpose: Isolates Bacillus cereus from faeces.
  • Key Components: Mannitol, egg yolk, polymyxin B, phenol red, agar.

3. Bacillus Cereus Agar (PEMBA):
  • Key Purpose: Selective isolation and enumeration of Bacillus cereus from food, animal feed, and environmental samples.
  • Characteristics of Bacillus Cereus: Turquoise-blue colonies (2-5 mm) with an opaque egg yolk precipitation zone (up to 5 mm wide). Confirm by hemolysis test on sheep blood agar or microscopic examination.

4. Xylose-Lysine-Desoxycholate (XLD) Agar:
  • Purpose: Isolates Salmonella and Shigella from the stool and mixed biota.
  • Key Components: Sodium desoxycholate, sucrose, lactose, xylose, phenol red, lysine, sodium thiosulfate, ferric ammonium citrate.
  • Colony Types:
    1. Yellow colonies (e.g., E. coli)
    2. Yellow with black centres (e.g., Citrobacter, some Proteus spp.)
    3. Colourless/red colonies (e.g., Shigella, Providencia)
    4. Red with black centres (e.g., Salmonella, Edwardsiella)

questions.text: Which medium is specifically used for processing urine specimens and differentiates between lactose fermenters (LF) and non-lactose fermenters (NLF) producing a yellow colour with LF?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) CLED Agar

 

Explanation:

  • Differential media differentiate between two groups of bacteria by using an indicator, which changes the colour of the colonies of a particular group of bacteria but not the other group.
  • CLED Agar (Cysteine Lactose Electrolyte-Deficient Agar) is used for processing urine specimens and differentiates between lactose fermenters (LF) and non-lactose fermenters (NLF) based on colony colour change.

 

Differential media
Medium Composition & Use Differentiation

MacConkey

(Option A)
  • A differential and selective medium primarily used for isolating enteric gram-negative bacteria.
  • Peptone, lactose, agar, neutral red (indicator), taurocholate
 Lactose Fermenters (LF): Pink colonies (e.g., Escherichia coli); Non-Lactose Fermenters (NLF): Colorless colonies (e.g., Shigella species)

CLED Agar

(Option B)
  • Cysteine lactose electrolyte-deficient agar
  • Processing of urine specimens
 LF produces a yellow color and NLF differentiated based on colony color change

Blood Agar

(Option C)
  • Agar, blood, cysteine, hemin
  • Growth of most aerobic and anaerobic bacteria; indicates hemolysis
  • Beta hemolysis: Complete lysis (clear zone, e.g., Group A Streptococci);
  • Alpha hemolysis: Partial lysis (greenish discolouration, e.g., Viridans Streptococci);
  • No hemolysis: No change (e.g., Enterococci)

 

Chocolate agar (Option D) is an enriched medium made by heating blood agar, which lyses red blood cells and releases nutrients such as haemoglobin and NAD. It supports the growth of fastidious bacteria such as Haemophilus and Neisseria species. It is not a differential media.

questions.text:
Match the transport medium with the organism it is commonly used for:

 


	
		
			
			1. Stuart medium
			
			
			a) Vibrio cholerae
			
		
		
			
			2. VR medium
			
			
			b) Shigella, Salmonella
			
		
		
			
			3. Buffered glycerol saline
			
			
			c) Neisseria
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1-c, 2-a, 3-b

 

Explanation:

  • Transport Media are designed for transporting specimens suspected to contain fastidious or delicate organisms, especially when there may be a delay in transporting the specimens from the collection site to the laboratory.
  • Characteristics:
    • Non-nutrient, soft agar gels
    • Contain reducing agents to prevent oxidation
    • Include substances like charcoal to neutralize bacterial inhibitors
    • Bacteria do not multiply in these media but remain viable

 

Organism

Transport media

Neisseria
  • Amies medium
  • Stuart's medium

Vibrio cholerae
  • VR (Venkatraman-Ramakrishnan) medium
  • Autoclaved seawater
  • Cary Blair medium

Shigella, Salmonella
  • Buffered glycerol saline
  • Cary Blair medium

questions.text: Which medium is specifically designed with an oxygen indicator and supports growth at different levels based on oxygen requirements?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Thioglycollate broth

Explanation:

  • Anaerobic media are used to grow anaerobic organisms in the presence of reducing substances or the absence of oxygen
  • Thioglycollate broth contains an oxygen indicator and supports growth at different levels within the medium based on oxygen requirements: obligate aerobes at the top, microaerophiles in the middle, and anaerobes at the bottom.

 

Anaerobic Media ​​​​​​​

Media Uses Picture

Robertson’s cooked meat broth

(Option A)
  • Contains chopped beef hearts providing glutathione and unsaturated fatty acids.
  • Widely used for anaerobic culture and stock cultures.

Thioglycollate broth

(Option B)
  • Supports the growth of organisms with varying oxygen needs.
  • Boiled to remove oxygen; an indicator shows oxygen levels (pink or blue).
  • Layers for obligate aerobes (top)-D, microaerophiles (middle)-C, and anaerobes (bottom)-B.
  • Contains yeast extract, casitone, sodium chloride, l-cystine, thioglycollic acid, agar, and methylene blue.

BHI (Brain Heart Infusion) Agar

(Option C)
  • Nutritious medium with calf brain and cow heart infusion.
  • Contains peptone, dextrose, vitamin K, and hemin.
  • Cultivation of fastidious organisms.

Other Anerobic media;

  • Anaerobic blood agar (Option D)
  • Neomycin blood agar
  • Egg yolk agar
  • Phenyl ethyl agar
  • Bacteroides bile esculin agar (BBE agar)

questions.text: Which is the most commonly used method for anaerobiosis, especially for laboratories with less sample load that uses reduced methylene blue as a chemical indicator?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) GasPak system

 

Explanation:

  • Anaerobic methods involve creating oxygen-free environments using techniques like evacuation and replacement with inert gases (e.g., hydrogen) and chemical reactions to remove residual oxygen, essential for culturing obligate anaerobic bacteria in laboratories.
  • GasPak System uses chemical reactions to remove oxygen. It is the most commonly used method for anaerobiosis, especially for laboratories with less sample load using reduced methylene blue as a chemical indicator.

ANAEROBIC METHODS

Method

Uses

 Image

McIntosh and Filde’s Anaerobic Jar (Option D)
  • Manual Method of Evacuation and replacement of air with hydrogen gas.
  • Catalyst: Aluminum pellets coated with palladium.
  • Usage: Less common now due to automation but was historically popular

GasPak System (Option B)
  • Principle: Uses chemical reactions to remove oxygen.
  • Components: Includes a sachet with sodium borohydride and sodium bicarbonate.
  • Catalyst: Aluminum pellets coated with palladium.
  • Indicator: Uses reduced methylene blue as a chemical indicator.

Other methods:

  • Anoxomat
  • Anaerobic Glove Box and Anaerobic Work Station
  • Pre-reduced Anaerobically Sterilized (PRAS) Media
  • GENbag

 

Anoxomat (Option A) automatically replaces air with hydrogen gas from a cylinder. Claims high effectiveness in creating anaerobic conditions.

 

Anaerobic Glove Box (Option C) provides a controlled environment for handling specimens without oxygen exposure.

questions.text: What is the Minimal Inhibitory Concentration (MIC) of an antibiotic?

choices.text: The highest concentration of the antibiotic that inhibits bacterial growth
The lowest concentration of the antibiotic that inhibits bacterial growth
The lowest concentration of the antibiotic that kills the bacteria
The highest concentration of the antibiotic that kills the bacteria

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) The lowest concentration of the antibiotic that inhibits bacterial growth

 

Explanation:

  • Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing (AST) helps clinicians choose appropriate antibiotics by determining which drugs are effective against the specific bacteria causing the infection. AST is conducted only on pathogenic bacteria isolated from clinical specimens, not on commensal bacteria.
  • MIC is defined as the lowest concentration of an antibiotic that prevents visible growth of the microorganism in a standardized growth medium. (Options A & D ruled out)

 

Minimal Inhibitory Concentration (MIC)
  • The lowest concentration of the antibiotic that inhibits the growth of the pathogen in the medium.

Minimal Bactericidal Concentration (MBC)
  • The lowest concentration of antibiotic that kills the bacteria in a medium.

Methods
  • Dilution method
  • Disc diffusion method
  • E-Test (combo of first two methods)
  • Automated methods

 

Clinical significance of MIC:

  • If MIC > breakpoint value, then there is resistance
  • If MIC < breakpoint value, then there is sensitivity

 

The lowest concentration of the antibiotic that kills the bacteria (Option C): This definition describes the minimal bactericidal concentration (MBC), not the MIC.

questions.text: In the Broth Dilution Method, what medium is typically used for serial dilutions of the antimicrobial agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Mueller-Hinton broth

 

Explanation:

Mueller-Hinton broth is used in the Broth Dilution Method for serial dilutions of the antimicrobial agent.

Minimum Inhibitory Concentration (MIC): Lowest concentration of antimicrobial agent that inhibits visible growth after overnight incubation.

Minimal bactericidal concentration (MBC): The lowest concentration of antibiotic that kills the bacteria in a medium.

 

1. Agar Dilution Method:

  • Serial dilutions in molten agar (Option A ruled out), poured into Petri dishes, spot inoculates test strain.
  • Advantages:
    • Test several strains simultaneously on the same plate.
    • Directly measures MBC without the need for subculturing.

2. Broth Dilution Method:

  • Types: Macro broth dilution (tubes) and micro broth dilution (microtiter plate).
  • Procedure:
    • Serial dilutions in Mueller-Hinton broth, inoculate with test organism, incubate at 37°C for 18 hours.
    • Determine MIC: by lowest concentration with no visible growth (clear broth).
    • Determine MBC: In Subculture tubes with no growth onto nutrient agar, the lowest concentration with no growth on subculture is MBC.

Sabouraud dextrose agar (Option C) and Blood agar (Option D) are not used in Diffusion methods.

questions.text: Which statement is NOT true regarding the Kirby-Bauer method?

choices.text: Apply 4-6 antibiotic discs per 9 cm plate
Factors such as the nature and composition of the medium can influence the zone diameter.
Disc concentration does not affect the zone of inhibition diameter.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Disc concentration does not affect the zone of inhibition diameter.

 

Explanation:

Disc concentration is one of the Factors Influencing Zone Diameter

 

KIRBY-BAUER METHOD

Step

Description

Inoculation
  • Use a standard dilution of a broth culture of the test bacterium.
  • Inoculate the surface of a solid medium (Cation-adjusted Mueller-Hinton agar (CAMHA) as a lawn culture.

Application of Antibiotic Discs
  • Dry the plate at 37°C for 30 minutes.
  • Apply 4-6 antibiotic discs per 9 cm plate with sterile forceps. (Option A ruled out)

Incubation
  • Incubate overnight. (Option C ruled out)
  • Measure the zones of inhibition around the discs to determine sensitivity.
  • Growth inhibition occurs around discs with effective antibiotics.

Factors Influencing Zone Diameter
  • Diffusibility of the drug
  • Disc concentration
  • Nature and composition of the medium (Option B ruled out)
  • Medium thickness
  • Presence of inhibitory or stimulatory substances
  • pH
  • Incubation time

Potency Check

Periodically check the potency of discs using standard ATCC strains:

  • S. aureus ATCC 25923
  • E. coli ATCC 25922
  • P. aeruginosa ATCC 27853

Interpretation of Results
  • Record zones of inhibition around the discs.
  • Interpret using zone diameters from CLSI guidelines or EUCAST guidelines.

 

Zone of inhibition around antibiotic discs in Kirby Bauer Test

questions.text: In antibiotic susceptibility testing using the Stokes Method, bacteria susceptible to the drug at higher than normal dosages are termed as:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Intermediately susceptible

 

Explanation:

Intermediately Susceptible bacteria are Susceptible to the drugs at higher dosages or when the drug has clinical efficacy at the body site where the drugs are physiologically concentrated.

 

STOKES METHOD:

  • Comparison of zones of inhibition: between standard & test bacteria.
  • Indicates sensitivity/resistance of bacteria.

Bacterial Sensitivity:

  • Susceptible: Inhibited by drug concentration achieved in blood at the recommended dosage. (Option A ruled out)
  • Intermediately Susceptible: Susceptible at higher dosages or effective at physiologically concentrated sites.
  • Resistant: Not inhibited; specific resistance mechanisms present. (Option B ruled out)

Choice of Antibiotic Disk:

  • Tests clinically relevant antibiotics.
  • Example:
    • Chloramphenicol is unnecessary for urinary pathogens (mostly excreted inactive).
    • Nitrofurantoin is relevant only for urinary pathogens.

 

Extremely susceptible (Option D) is not defined under Stoke’s Method

questions.text: In a 65 y/o male with COPD showing signs of a bacterial respiratory infection, the sputum sample undergoes culture and sensitivity testing using the Epsilometer (E-test). Following incubation, an elliptical zone of inhibition is observed around the antibiotic strip. What is the primary advantage of using the E-test in this clinical context?

choices.text: It identifies the specific bacterium causing the infection.
It determines the bacterium's resistance to all known antibiotics.
It provides a visual and precise measurement of the minimum inhibitory concentration of the antibiotic.
It allows for the immediate administration of antibiotics without further testing.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) It provides a visual and precise measurement of the minimum inhibitory concentration of the antibiotic.

Explanation:

The primary advantage of the E-test is that it provides a clear, visual indication of the MIC, which is the lowest concentration of an antibiotic that inhibits the growth of the bacterium. This helps clinicians choose the most effective antibiotic and dosage for treatment.

Image showing E-test

 

Step

Description

Setup

An absorbent strip with a gradient of antibiotic concentrations is placed on a culture plate inoculated with the bacterium.

Process

The strip releases the antibiotic, creating a gradient in the medium. An elliptical zone of inhibition forms around the strip after incubation.

Determination

The MIC is identified at the point where the edge of the ellipse intersects with the strip, representing the lowest concentration of the antibiotic that inhibits bacterial growth (MIC). (Option C)

Advantages

Allows for the simultaneous testing of multiple antibiotics on a single plate and provides a visual, precise measurement of the MIC, enhancing accuracy compared to traditional disk diffusion methods.

 

It identifies the specific bacterium causing the infection (Option A): The E-test assesses bacterial susceptibility to antibiotics but does not identify the specific bacterium. Additional tests like culture characteristics, biochemical tests, or molecular methods are needed for bacterial identification.

It determines the bacterium's resistance to all known antibiotics (Option B): The E-test measures the MIC for specific antibiotics tested, not for all known antibiotics. Multiple E-tests with different antibiotics can be performed to get a broader resistance profile, but each test is specific to one antibiotic.

It allows for the immediate administration of antibiotics without further testing (Option D): While the E-test provides valuable information, it still requires incubation and interpretation time. Immediate administration of antibiotics is typically guided by clinical judgment and empirical therapy, not solely by the results of the E-test.
